raw_text:
Costin aims for comeback in 2006
 
 Jamie Costin should be paralysed.
 
 He says so himself in a matter-of-fact way as he recalls the car accident which occurred nine days before he was scheduled to step out into the Olympic Stadium in Athens for the 50K Walk. There is an ironic chuckle as he talks of his immediate thoughts after a lorry, driving on the wrong side of the road, had ploughed into his rental car. "I was in a lot of pain and I guessed that one of my toes was broken," says the Waterford man. "But I was thinking maybe with a cortisone injection you never know. "In my back, it felt as though all the muscles had been ripped off my pelvis but I was thinking maybe we could do something with laser therapy and ultra sound and hopefully I'd be able to race." It took over 10 hours before Jamie knew with certainty that he would not be competing in his second Olympics. "My back had been broken in two places and with one of my vertebrae, the bottom part had exploded so I'm fierce lucky not be paralysed. "I'd fractured my big toe as well which was on the brake." Jamie didn't finally arrive at hospital in Athens until some nine and a half hours after the accident.
 
 "For the first nine hours, I had no pain killers which was ridiculous in 35 degrees heat. "But once I got the scans and saw them it was a case of moving on and thinking:'OK, I've got a different set of circumstances now'." Within three days he was arriving back in Ireland by air ambulance. Doctors in Athens had wanted to operate on Jamie's back immediately but he insisted on delaying any surgery until he arrived back home - something he is now very relieved about. "The Greek doctors were going to put three or four inch titanium rods either side of my spinal cord up through my vertebrae. "That would have fused all my lower back and I would never have been able to race again. They were really putting a lot of pressure on me to agree to the surgery. "But when I got to the Mater in Dublin they said it was possible for it to heal totally naturally which is giving me the chance to get back into competition which is very important to me. The people at the Mater have been absolutely fantastic." Jamie had to wear a body cast for three and a half months after the accident and spent most of that time flat on his back.
 
 He then progressed to crutches for six weeks until he was finally able to walk unaided on 10 January. "Walking without the crutches seemed like something finally really measurable in terms of my recovery." Physio sessions with Johnston McEvoy in Limerick have been a vital part of his recovery. "Johnston uses an advanced type of acupuncture and it's very effective. "Needles get put right close up to my spine. A two and a half inch needle went in yesterday and I'm fairly incapacitated today as a result." Jamie has also travelled to receive treatment at the Polish training centre in Spala where he has trained with triple Olympic champion Robert Korzeniowski over the past five years. "I was there for over a fortnight earlier this month and underwent a fair extreme treatment called cryotherapy. "Basically, there's a small room which is cooled by liquid nitrogen to minus 160 degrees centigrade and it promotes deep healing."
 
 Jamie heads to Poland again on Sunday where he will be having daily cryotherapy in addition to twice-daily physio sessions and pool-work. All these sessions are small steps on the way to what Jamie hopes will be a return to racing in 2006. "It's all about trying to get mobility in my back. Lying down for three and a half months didn't really help with the strength. "There's a lot of work involved in my recovery. I'm doing about six hours a day between physio and pool work. "I'm also going to the gym to lift very light weights to try and build up my muscles. I'm fairly full on with everything I do. "I'd hope to be training regularly by March. But training is just part of the process of getting back. "At the moment, every time I go and do a big bit of movement, my whole pelvic area all down my lower back just tightens up. "It's a case of waiting and seeing how it reacts. Hopefully, after four or five months my back won't tighten up as much."
llama3.2:1b: Jamie Costin aims to return to competition in 2006 due to a severe back injury that occurred during the Olympic Stadium in Athens.
The accident resulted in paralysis on one side of his spine and left him with broken bones in his legs, specifically his big toe.
llama3.2:3b: Jamie Costin was involved in a car accident nine days before his 50K Walk Olympic event in Athens in 2006, resulting in multiple injuries including broken vertebrae and fractured toes.

He spent over 10 hours in pain before receiving scans and delayed surgery until returning home to Ireland, where he received treatment from the Mater Hospital and underwent advanced therapies like laser therapy and acupuncture.

He has been recovering for over a year and is now focused on regaining mobility and strength in his back through daily physio sessions, pool work, and cryotherapy, aiming to return to competition by March 2006.
gemma2:2b: Jamie Costin suffered a severe car accident nine days before the start of his second Olympic Games in Athens, resulting in a broken back and toe.
He endured intense pain but managed to stay positive and delayed surgery until returning home to Ireland.
Doctors confirmed he had fractured vertebrae, urging him for immediate surgery, but Jamie was confident in his body's ability to heal naturally with proper care and a focus on physiotherapy.
He traveled to Poland for specialized treatment with Robert Korzeniowski, including cryotherapy.
Costin aims to return to competitive walking in 2006 after extensive physical therapy, acupuncture, and rigorous training regimes.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Jamie Costin is paralyzed from the waist down due to a car accident in Athens.
He recovered slowly from the accident, but has since returned to racing and training.
He hopes to compete at the 2006 Olympics by returning to racing in 2006.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Jamie Costin, in 2006, recovers from an accident that left him paralyzed, undergoing advanced medical treatments and rehabilitation to return to competitive running within the next year.
qwen2.5:3b: Jamie Costin aims to compete in the 2006 Olympics despite suffering a serious car accident nine days before his scheduled participation in Athens.
He initially thought he could race with injuries including broken toes and fractured vertebrae treated through therapies like cortisone injections, laser therapy, and ultra-sound.
However, it was later confirmed that his back was severely injured—broken in two places, with a vertebra exploding.
He nearly underwent surgery to fuse his lower spine but opted against it after being advised of the possibility for natural healing at home.
Costin spent over three months immobilized in a body cast and now uses crutches before transitioning to walking without aid by January 10th.
His recovery includes acupuncture, cryotherapy treatments from Poland, and gym workouts.
Despite challenges like muscle tightness, his goal is to return to full racing capabilities by March 2006.

It took over 10 hours before Jamie knew with certainty that he would not be competing in his second Olympics.
He had no pain kills and three days later he arrived back in Ireland by air ambulance.
"The Greek doctors were going to put three or four inch titanium rods either side of my vertebrae."
The people at the Mater have been absolutely fantastic.
Jamie has also travelled to receive treatment at the Polish training centre in Spala where he has trained with triple Olympic champion Robert Korzeniowski over the past five years.
He was there for over a fortnight earlier this month and underwent a fair extreme treatment called cryotherapy.
In addition to these sessions, physio sessions with Johnston McEvoy in Limerick have been a vital part of his recovery.

deepseek-r1:1.5b: Jamie Costin aims for a comeback in 2006 but is seriously injured.
He was recently injured by a lorry on the wrong side of the road at nine days before his Olympic Stadium appearance.
Jamie expressed concerns about his future participation, considering laser therapy and other treatments.
However, he struggles to return to competition, spending nearly three months in a body cast with crutches.

tinyllama:1.1b: The following is the abstract for a research paper on the recovery process after an injury in the Olympic Games, focusing specifically on the experience of Waterford man Jamie Costin.
The abstract follows the text-only format with key ideas and details preserved, without explanations or footnotes, with no additional formatting or reasoning process.
tinydolphin:1.1b: Jamie Costin, in an inspiring tale of resilience, describes his life-changing accident nine days before he was supposed to compete in the 2006 Olympics.
Having suffered severe injuries, including a broken pelvis and broken big toe, he initially struggled to walk and faced immense pain during recovery.
Despite this, Jamie persevered, using various treatment methods, such as physiotherapy with Johnston McEvoy in Limerick and cryotherapy in Poland, which helped him regain mobility in his back.
With a plan in place for physical therapy and daily physio sessions in addition to swimming and pool-work, Jamie is determined to return to the track in 2006.
phi:2.7b: Jamie Costin should be paralyzed due to his car accident in Greece nine days before the 200K Walk at the Olympics.
However, he will not be competing because his back was broken in two places and one of his vertebrae exploded.
He didn't take painkillers for the first nine hours as he waited in the hot Greek weather.
Once he got scans, it was a matter of moving on with "a different set of circumstances."
Jamie is grateful to have not been paralysed and to be able to race again.
Jamie had to wear a body cast for three and a half months after the accident before he could walk unaided using crutches for six weeks.
Physio sessions at the Mater Hospital in Dublin, with Johnston McEvoy, were vital in his recovery.
He also underwent cryotherapy treatment in Poland for over two weeks earlier this month to promote deep healing.
Jamie will return to Poland on Sunday where he will have daily cryotherapy and twice-daily physio sessions plus pool work.
His training is a small step towards getting back into competition by March 2006, but he must wait and see how his back reacts to the movements.
He plans to lift light weights at the gym to build his muscles.
orca-mini:3b: Jamie Costin aimed to return to competition in 2006 after suffering a broken back in an accident nine days before the Olympic Games in Athens.
He fractured his big toe and had to wear a body cast for three and a half months, followed by crutches for six weeks.
He underwent cryotherapy sessions and physio sessions with Johnston McEvoy in Limerick.
He returned to Ireland by air ambulance and spent most of the next three and a half months in recovery, progressing to crutches and then two-hour physio sessions with Johnston McEvoy.
His back was broken in two places and with one of his vertebrae, the bottom part had exploded so he is grateful not to be paralysed.
He hopes to train regularly by March and has been doing very light weights since being discharged from hospital.
hermes3:3b: Jamie Costin aims to come back from paralyzing car accident for walking competition in 2006, relying on natural recovery rather than surgery, physio sessions and treatments in Poland.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: Jamie Costin, an Olympic 50K Walk contender from the 2004 Athens Olympics, suffered a severe car accident resulting in a broken back and fractured toe.
He initially believed he could possibly undergo surgery to regain mobility, but doctors suggested it would hinder his racing career.
After delays, doctors at Mater Hospital in Dublin found that his spine could heal on its own with time.
Costin wore a body cast for three and a half months, progressed to using crutches, underwent physiotherapy with Johnston McEvoy, and received cryotherapy treatment in Poland.
He aims to return to racing in the 2006 season.
stablelm2:1.6b: Jamie Costin was set to compete in the Olympics but suffered a car accident that broke his back twice.
He underwent laser therapy and ultrasound to heal, eventually arriving at a natural healing center where physio sessions with Johnston McEvoy aided his recovery.
Cryotherapy treatments also helped him promote deep healing.
Despite regular workouts, it's still a process for him to regain mobility in his back.
He hopes to train regularly by March and expects to return to racing in 2016.
granite3.1-dense:2b: Jamie Costin, an Irish wheelchair athlete scheduled to compete in the 50K Walk at the 2004 Athens Olympics, suffered a severe car accident nine days before the event.
A lorry, driving on the wrong side of the road, collided with his rental car, causing extensive back injuries and a broken big toe.
Despite initial optimism that he might avoid paralysis, he was diagnosed with two fractured vertebrae and severe back damage, potentially threatening his ability to walk again.
After over 10 hours of delay before receiving medical attention in Athens, Costin learned he had a broken back and the bottom part of one vertebra had exploded.

He arrived back in Ireland within three days via air ambulance, where doctors recommended immediate surgery to fuse his lower spine with titanium rods but postponed it at his insistence due to hopes for natural healing.
Costin underwent extensive rehabilitation, including a three-and-a-half-month body cast, six weeks of crutches use, and acupuncture sessions with Johnston McEvoy in Limerick.
He also visited the Polish training center in Spala to receive cryotherapy treatment and train with triple Olympic champion Robert Korzeniowski.
In preparation for a potential return to racing in 2006, Costin now engages in daily cryotherapy in Poland alongside twice-daily physiotherapy sessions and pool work.
His intensive recovery program aims to restore mobility in his back and strengthen his pelvic area.
While he currently experiences tightness when performing movements, he remains optimistic about returning to competition by March.
chatgpt-4o-latest: Jamie Costin, an Irish race walker, survived a severe car accident just before the 2004 Olympics, suffering multiple fractures, including a broken back.
Initially pressured to undergo spinal surgery in Greece, he opted for natural healing in Ireland, which preserved his chances of returning to competition.
His recovery involved wearing a body cast for months, using crutches, and undergoing extensive physiotherapy, including acupuncture and cryotherapy in Poland.
Committed to regaining mobility and strength, he follows an intense rehabilitation regimen and hopes to resume training by March 2006, aiming for a competitive comeback.
